page.title: 02Rogart - Landscape
page.content: From The Bank downwards, the road is lined with birch and blackthorn trees. On the banks of the Corry Burn wood anemones, celandines, daisies, violets, daffodils and primroses abound. The low ground is covered with rough grazing. When we climb a little, the hillside is covered with heather, some of which has been burned recently. Grazing in the fields are Cheviot sheep and Hereford, Aberdeen Angus and Shorthorn cattle. Rabbits are in plentiful supply. Indeed, the crofters have erected a rabbit fence in an attempt to keep them off the grazing areas. There are a great number of birds here. The most notable being ospreys,eagles and sparrow-hawks. Foxes, roe-deer, red deer and Scottish wild cats are common.
